posts.name: Linus T. (they/them)
posts.cooked: I‚Äôd like to suggest to add the option to add gender pronouns to a profile if you want to. There is such a feature on other messaging platforms like Discord for example and it‚Äôs kind of missing on signal.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
while i very much support there being a separate field (as a way to lightly encourage everyone to fill it out), i will mention that right now as a workaround you can just put it as your ‚Äúlast name‚Äù or as part of it when filling out your profile.

Screenshot_20250122_210645707√ó474 31.7 KB

Screenshot_20250122_210701707√ó474 16.6 KB

rassilon1963:

you can just put it as your ‚Äúlast name‚Äù or as part of it when filling out your profile.

You can also put extra content in the ‚ÄúAbout me‚Äù section of your profile.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Right, Signal is a messaging application to message people. For this, pronouns are indeed relevant, as they are part of the language you use to communicate on Signal.
A lot of languages make it grammatically way harder then english to communicate with someone without using a pronoun because no neutral forms exist.
Having to guess the pronouns from a name is not a solution. There are a lot of names, especially from languages I don‚Äôt speak, which I‚Äôve never heard before and have no clue which pronouns might be commonly used for that name.
Helping you to avoid awkward situation where you accidentally guess a wrong pronoun of your conversation partner (e.g. business partner, co-worker, customer) would in my opinion increase the usability of Signal. I hope we all agree that usability is not ‚Äútrivia‚Äù.
Why is the ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù section on the profile not an appropriate place for this kind of information? It seems like the perfect place to tell people about yourself.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
well, as said even by people who support this feature, you can always use the existing fields, which makes this FR less urgent (though not less valid - a workaround is not a fix).
however, the ‚Äúabout‚Äù field specifically is less fitting, since it‚Äôs not immediately visible in the chat, while pronoun information is something that should be immediately visible (and is arguably even more important than the last name being shown - not that i ask for the last name to be hidden.)

i‚Äôve already given my workaround which works well enough for me. but again, a workaround is not a solution, and there‚Äôs a good reason a bunch of modern chat apps implement a separate field.

Gender pronouns Feature Requests
while i very much support there being a separate field (as a way to lightly encourage everyone to fill it out), i will mention that right now as a workaround you can just put it as your ‚Äúlast name‚Äù or as part of it when filling out your profile. [Screenshot_20250122_210645] [Screenshot_20250122_210701]

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: btw this is a bit late in the discussion to do that but i‚Äôve reworded the title a bit to make clear we‚Äôre talking about a profile field

I think that the pronoun dialogue has gone too far in most aspects, but in Signal it can have a place from at least two perspectives:

1a. Signal is used by some for anonymity. Many will not place their actual names in the Signal profile, thus even if one could deduce a gender from a first name, it might not be available. A gender field can help to prevent confusion.

1b. Signal is used by some for anonymity. If I were trying to confuse others as to my identity, intentionally selecting a gender other than my own could be a way to further confusion.

2 . Signal is a communication tool that is used globally. While I think that my first name is able to convey my gender, those who use different languages may not. I work with many people of far-east Asian decent. I am often unable to determine their genders based solely on their first names.

I wouldn‚Äôt personally use this but I really like the idea. And I think it should be something that‚Äôs easily visible in a chat too.

It would also be cool (imo) if you could choose which contacts and groups to share pronouns with, so they can sometimes be kept hidden or shared only selectively. But this would of course be more complex to implement than simply adding a field.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Pronoun fields are a way that people can express their identities in a concise way, much like ‚Äústatus‚Äù or ‚Äúbio‚Äù fields.

If you believe that someone displaying the words they would like to be addressed by is somehow politically-charged, you have been misled.

The discussion about whether or not this feature should be implemented should only be about technical details, not about how someone chooses to identify themself.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Replies that are offtopic, from both sides of the conversation, have been hidden from this thread.

I think it‚Äôs important to reiterate that just because you disagree with something or won‚Äôt use it, that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not relevant or necessary to others.

A feature request is intended to offer one person‚Äôs idea as a suggestion to the Signal Community. A request does not guarantee implementation or even acknowledgement by Signal. I think a lot of people forget this.

If you don‚Äôt have anything useful to say, then there‚Äôs no need to reply. This community is diverse and consists of people from all over the world from all different backgrounds. Let‚Äôs keep an open mind and avoid arguing, please.

I agree that it would be really useful to have the pronouns be visible in the chat much like they would appear now if added to the last name.

Especially in large groups where you might not know everyone, it‚Äôs very useful to be able to use the correct pronouns for everyone.
Names are a really unreliable way to guess pronouns and this is a super simple and straightforward way to make conversation smoother and less awkward.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i mentioned it shortly before the thread cleanup but i think it‚Äôs worth to say it again separated from the noise.

to me the best implementation is just like there is a field titled first name and a field titled last name, a third field, on equal footing, titled ‚Äúpronouns‚Äù. it should be an empty textbox, optional, and essentially be like the last name field.
there are different implementations out there (just as one example, Pixelfed has a long list of pronouns and lets you choose up to 4), but i much prefer the open textbox option, as it‚Äôs more inclusive of people in different linguistic environments (non-English speakers, people who want to specify pronouns in multiple languages, etc).

as for what it should look like, i think the Fedilab Fediverse client did a pretty good job:

0922d6331879c35b1080√ó345 55.4 KB

screenshot taken from this post:

LGBTQIA+ and Tech ‚Äì 4 Feb 24

Natasha Jay üá™üá∫ (@Natasha_Jay@tech.lgbt)

Attached: 4 images If you add a new "Pronouns" field in your profile, the latest Fedilab app version now displays them automatically after your name Very nice small touch, the Fediverse :fediverse: needs to know of this (and thank you Fedilab -...

link_counts.title: Natasha Jay üá™üá∫: "If you add a new "Pronouns" field in your profile‚Ä¶" - LGBTQIA+ and Tech

posts.cooked: I worded my comment the way that I did intentionally. An optional gender field can be helpful when the information in one‚Äôs profile does not easily convey this information. I don‚Äôt like pronoun fields either.

I think the issue with a gender field is that it doesn‚Äôt specify how someone wants to be referred to - it just describes an attribute.

Displaying someone‚Äôs pronouns, on the other hand, doesn‚Äôt describe an attribute, it makes it clear what language to use when referring to them.

This also means that, by displaying pronouns, people don‚Äôt have to directly disclose their gender.

Also, to go back to my previous post, in addition to choosing whom to share one‚Äôs own pronouns with, there could be a global option to not show other people‚Äôs pronouns at all. So, anyone not interested in displaying (or storing) such information about their contacts - perhaps because it‚Äôs not safe to do so - could turn it off.

But, maybe just a field would be enough to start!

I think something like the Fedilab example mentioned above would work well. And in group chats pronouns could be displayed alongside names at the top of each message?
Where is this information supposed to show up in the application? ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù is only shown in a few places, at least as far as I know.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
which is why i‚Äôm not in favour of using the ‚Äúabout‚Äù.
this is what it looks like when adding it manually to the last name field. i expect it to look somewhat similar - either parantheses with what the person inputted, or smaller text, or something similar that‚Äôs visually distinct from the self-inputted name but that appears in the same contexts.

Screenshot_20250124_101148699√ó494 28.4 KB

I‚Äôm wondering if a more generic ‚Äúcall me‚Äù field wouldn‚Äôt be more universal. Many languages don‚Äôt have grammatical gender, but may have other features that affect how one may wish to be addressed.

posts.name: Linus T. (they/them)
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

Where is this information supposed to show up in the application?

It could be placed in the head bar for private chats; something like this:

2025-01-24-102759_hyprshot1167√ó150 26.3 KB

And maybe like this in group chats:
2025-01-24-103001_hyprshot732√ó204 27.2 KB

It could also be placed next to the time a message was sent if it is supposed to look the same in every type of chat.
In the chat list the pronouns could simply be displayed next to the name in a slightly weaker colour or in italic to separate it from the name.

RibbonMotto:

there could be a global option to not show other people‚Äôs pronouns at all

I think if such a setting would be added, it should be disabled by default so people don‚Äôt have to make any afford for seeing other‚Äôs pronouns.
If people first had to enable pronouns, they may leave them off or don‚Äôt even get to know the feature which kind of eliminates the point of having pronouns displayed in the application. but if some are bothered by others showing this part of their identity they can still disable the feature.

TeeJay82:

I‚Äôm wondering if a more generic ‚Äúcall me‚Äù field wouldn‚Äôt be more universal. Many languages don‚Äôt have grammatical gender, but may have other features that affect how one may wish to be addressed.

That‚Äôs a good thought. I think the way this information would be displayed is pretty similar to a pronouns field. So the field could just be called ‚Äúcall me‚Äù instead of ‚Äúpronouns‚Äù and everyone can input what‚Äôs best working with their language.

posts.name: tubby
posts.cooked: You can add male and female genders to your bio
